Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story: I was looking forward to this week—finally, a stretch of evenings free with Alex. We’d been talking about trying that new Italian place, maybe catching a movie after. He’d been dropping hints about how much he missed our long, unhurried conversations. I promised him I’d make time, that work wouldn’t get in the way. But today, as I stood in court, reading jury instructions, my clerk slipped me a note. The Supreme Court had just issued a ruling—one that completely upended the precedent I was relying on. My heart pounded. I knew I had to stop, review the new decision, and rewrite my instructions. The legal community would expect me to be on top of this, to set the right example. But all I could think about was the dinner reservation I’d made for tonight, the look on Alex’s face if I canceled again. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, and I felt myself caught in the impossible space between them.
